annotation.spannedText: The medical community vociferously denies any connection between the MMR vaccine and autism

classMention.mentionClass: The medical community vociferously denies any connection between the MMR vaccine and autism

annotation.spannedText: Atypical patterns of exposure to common childhood infections -- measles, mumps, rubella and chickenpox -- have been associated with autism and autistic regression

classMention.mentionClass: Atypical patterns of exposure to common childhood infections -- measles, mumps, rubella and chickenpox -- have been associated with autism and autistic regression

annotation.spannedText: A close temporal relationship in the exposure to two of these infections during periods of susceptibility may compound both the risk and severity of autism

classMention.mentionClass: A close temporal relationship in the exposure to two of these infections during periods of susceptibility may compound both the risk and severity of autism

annotation.spannedText: Although historically, these rare patterns of exposure may have accounted for only a small proportion of autism, the widespread use of a combination of the candidate agents in a single vaccine [MMR] may have changed this

annotation.spannedText: fetuses and young children are especially prone to adverse consequences if they contract two or more viral infections concurrently

annotation.spannedText: if a child who is exposed to two or more wild viral infections around the same time is at increased risk for autism, then a child who is injected with three live viruses via the MMR vaccine is equally susceptible to the ailment, if not more so

annotation.spannedText: Dr. Wakefield

classMention.mentionClass: Dr. Wakefield

annotation.spannedText: His solution would satisfy immunization recommendations designed to protect against the three diseases while safeguarding against the risk of autism

classMention.mentionClass: His solution would satisfy immunization recommendations designed to protect against the three diseases while safeguarding against the risk of autism

annotation.spannedText: Spacing the single vaccines, thereby dissociating the exposures that, together, may constitute the risk, provides a way of not only preventing the acute measles, mumps and rubella infections, but also, potentially, the risk of one of the most devastating diseases that it has been our misfortune to encounter
